repnme.cdata!:
Guatemala - Financial Sector Technical
            Assistance Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Financial Sector
            Technical Assistance Loan (FSTAL) Project for Guatemala were
            as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: it is desirable
            to retain a degree of flexibility in the project to allow
            adjustments to respond to changing priorities within the
            overall framework of the operation. Broad definition of the
            disbursement categories can contribute to such flexibility
            and facilitate the movement of funds without difficult
            formal reallocations. This is particularly relevant if the
            implementation period is lengthy, there is a risk that
            individual priorities become less relevant. The preparation
            of the project counted with the strong commitment of both
            the highest levels of Government and the implementing
            agencies. The successful development of regulations for the
            resolution of insolvent banks, the new handbook of Risk
            Based Supervision (RBS) and the chapter on consolidated
            supervision were all due not only to the high quality of
            international consultants recruited but also the commitment
            made by the authorities in providing technical resources and
            personnel exclusively dedicated to these tasks. Importantly,
            as technical capacity was build and the new supervisory
            vision was institutionalized, the Superintendency of Banks
            (SB) claimed clear ownership, reflected in their commitment
            to continue such work beyond the lifespan of the FSTAL.

repnme.cdata!:
Guatemala - Financial Sector Technical
            Assistance Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Sector Technical
            Assistance Loan Project will support implementation of the
            Government's financial sector reform program, by
            providing technical assistance (TA) in banking systems, able
            to improve, and expand its intermediating functions, and to
            withstand shocks. The project components will: 1) provide
            rapid exit and resolution of insolvent banks, by financing
            TA to the Super-intendency of Banks (SB) to establish
            benchmarks to assess viability, and solvency of banks, by
            designing templates to prepare, and evaluate bank's
            rehabilitation plans. Legal and financial instruments will
            be designed for the transfer of liabilities from insolvent,
            to solvent banks, and for the transfer of assets to a
            special trust while compensation mechanisms will be
            established for institutions acquiring assets, and
            liabilities from insolvent banks; 2) establish the Fiduciary
            Fund for Bank Capitalization, providing TA for its
            operation, including the design of financial instruments to
            capitalize viable banks. Policy and strategic formulation
            will be addressed, and the evolution of capitalized banks
            will be monitored; 3) finance TA to establish a credit
            information system to centralize, organize, and maintain
            information of debtors of financial institutions in
            Guatemala. The acquisition of operational software and
            hardware will encourage better lending practices, and
            improve the overall financial system; and, 4) finance TA to
            strengthen the Special Unit Against Money Laundering,
            including training, and supervisory assistance. Moreover, TA
            will support the adoption of international accounting
            standards by the Central Bank, and a strategy for the
            financial system development.
